org.bsiet.combinations

Class LabelledPasswordField

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent
          • javax.swing.JPanel
            • org.bsiet.combinations.LabelledPasswordField
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible

    public class LabelledPasswordField
extends javax.swing.JPanel
    Since:
    1.7
    Author:
    The Java Wizard Development team

    Use

    A component that gives you JLabel and JPasswordField next to it as a single component aligned in GroupLayout.
    You can even choose whether you want its alignment in HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL orientation.
    It supports all methods supported by both JLabel and JPasswordField
    This component is returned in JPanel. So you either can initialize it as object or can store it in JPanel too.

    Sample Class


    import javax.swing.JPanel;
    import org.bsiet.combinations.LabelledPasswordField;
    import org.bsiet.layouts.MyLayout;

    public class LabelledPasswordFieldSample extends JPanel {

    LabelledPasswordField lpf1, lpf2;

    public LabelledPasswordFieldSample()
    {
    lpf1 = new LabelledPasswordField("Password", 10);

    lpf2 = new LabelledPasswordField("Password", 10, true);

    MyLayout ml = new MyLayout(new Object[]{lpf1, lpf2}, true);
    add(ml);
    }

    }
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • MIN_LENGTH

        public static final int MIN_LENGTH
        The Constant MIN_LENGTH. Takes the default minimum length of the password.
        Final value is 6.
        Since:
        1.7
